We're applying for a grant and we need to professionalize our language. Can you reword this in a way that a professional grant writer would do? Do not drastically change the text, just adapt it slightly to increase professionalism:
Project outline: 

Location: South Lebanon, Greater Beirut Area, Mount Lebanon, North Lebanon, Bekaa
Duration: 1 to 2 years 


Project Summary 

Many economists believe that getting back on track, and achieving financial stability, developing countries such as Lebanon need to focus their investments on their internal resources such as the Food & Beverage sector and the tourism sector. Many of the Lebanese population have already taken that step and started their own small scale Agro-food and Mounet production, and many are now eligible to take their business a step further and produce on a bigger scale and cater to a larger market. 

This project aims to support small local Lebanese food-production businesses and get them up and running on their own, which will eventually impact their standards of living as a community and the standards of the Lebanese population as a whole. Local entrepreneurs that meet the project’s selection criteria will be provided with the right guidance and trainings by professional food-safety experts and business experts to equip them with better knowledge on how to produce quality-improved products and how to use their competitive edge to integrate themselves and compete in bigger markets, all while ensuring an efficient delivery system and maintaining food safety standards and making them eligible for Label attainment. As a way to assess the new food production performance, entrepreneurs are to submit their old and new product for Pre and Post assessment which if succeeded, will become eligible to obtain a certification label on their products which will grant them an advantage to compete on a larger scale and possibly export their products.  Acquiring the Label, small food-production businesses will enhance brand recognition and guarantee product quality to customers. They also prove to internal and later on external authorities that the production site is safe and legal. In addition, small producers will benefit from being positioned as Certified Food Production Facility which will:

Project Outline:

Location: South Lebanon, Greater Beirut Area, Mount Lebanon, North Lebanon, Bekaa
Duration: 1 to 2 years

Project Summary:

Numerous economic experts assert that for developing nations like Lebanon to regain financial stability, it is vital to concentrate investment efforts on internal resources such as the Food & Beverage and tourism sectors. A significant portion of the Lebanese population has already begun establishing small-scale agro-food and Mounet production enterprises, with many now poised to expand their operations to a larger scale and reach broader markets.

This project aims to bolster small, local Lebanese food-production businesses, enabling them to become self-sufficient and, in turn, improve the standard of living for both their local communities and the Lebanese population as a whole. Local entrepreneurs who satisfy the project's selection criteria will receive expert guidance and training from professional food safety specialists and business advisors. This support will equip them with the knowledge necessary to enhance product quality, leverage their competitive advantage, and integrate into more extensive markets, all while maintaining food safety standards and ensuring efficient delivery systems.

Moreover, this project will facilitate eligibility for Label attainment, enabling businesses to demonstrate their commitment to quality and safety. To assess the efficacy of the new food production methods, entrepreneurs will submit their products for pre- and post-assessment, with successful participants becoming eligible to receive a certification label for their products. This certification will grant them a competitive edge in larger markets and, potentially, the ability to export their products.

By acquiring this Label, small food-production businesses will improve brand recognition and assure customers of their products' quality. Furthermore, they will provide evidence to both internal and external authorities that their production facilities are safe and compliant with regulations. In addition, these small producers will benefit from being identified as Certified Food Production Facilities, which will:

We're applying for a grant and we need to professionalize our language. Can you reword this in a way that a professional grant writer would do? Do not drastically change the text, just adapt it slightly to increase professionalism, grammar: 
Producer selection will be based on the results obtained through a series of questionnaires, surveys, and field visits to better assess their eligibility to this project. Collected data will be analyzed and projected as information on what type of assistance they should get and how. Based on those results, we will develop a detailed curriculum covering the following topics:

Good Manufacturing & Hygienic Practices Training
Marketing, digital marketing and branding/ Communication and Leadership
Introduction to Accounting and Cost Analysis: Training on efficient methods of accounting, proper cost analysis and bookkeeping
Personal development and soft skills

An excellent way to reach a goal is to learn and execute on the spot. During their training, Entrepreneurs are requested to draft their business plan covering their future strategy and predicts a 5-year growth proposal.

Selection of producers will be determined through the utilization of questionnaires, surveys, and field visits, which will enable a comprehensive assessment of their suitability for this project. The gathered data will be analyzed to ascertain the specific type and extent of assistance required for each participant. Based on these findings, we will develop a comprehensive curriculum that encompasses the following topics:

1. Good Manufacturing & Hygienic Practices Training
2. Marketing, Digital Marketing, and Branding/Communication and Leadership
3. Introduction to Accounting and Cost Analysis: Training on efficient methods of accounting, proper cost analysis, and bookkeeping
4. Personal Development and Soft Skills

An effective approach to achieving objectives is to combine learning with immediate implementation. During the training, entrepreneurs will be asked to develop a business plan outlining their future strategy and presenting a five-year growth projection.

Can you combine these two components of the proposal?
In Lebanon, small-scale agricultural producers are struggling to stay in business due to unfavorable and unstable economic conditions. Despite its relatively favorable environmental and agricultural conditions, Lebanon imports the majority of its agricultural goods due to producers’ low production abilities and knowledge.“According to Lebanese Customs statistics, Lebanon’s total agricultural imports reached $2.3 billion in 2021.” 

This proposed project aims to promote domestic agricultural production as an import substitution tool by building the capacity of Lebanese producers. The project will target around 700 producers from all over Lebanon. This is possible through designing and implementing a hybrid and innovative training curriculum for Lebanese producers on (1) technical and professional capacity building  and (2) universal and organizational/enterprise skills training. After completing the training, the Lebanese producers become eligible to (3) receive a nationally-recognized production label created and offered by the program that will act as a sign of quality to the consumers and consequently increase sales for domestic agricultural goods as well as grant local producers an advantage to compete on a larger scale and possibly export their products. This project will eventually impact the standards of living of the small local Lebanese food-production businesses, their community and the Lebanese population as a whole.

This:"In Lebanon, small-scale agricultural producers are struggling to stay in business due to unfavorable and unstable economic conditions. Despite its relatively favorable environmental and agricultural conditions, Lebanon imports the majority of its agricultural goods due to producers’ low production abilities and knowledge.“According to Lebanese Customs statistics, Lebanon’s total agricultural imports reached $2.3 billion in 2021.” 

This proposed project aims to promote domestic agricultural production as an import substitution tool by building the capacity of Lebanese producers. The project will target around 700 producers from all over Lebanon. This is possible through designing and implementing a hybrid and innovative training curriculum for Lebanese producers on (1) technical and professional capacity building  and (2) universal and organizational/enterprise skills training. After completing the training, the Lebanese producers become eligible to (3) receive a nationally-recognized production label created and offered by the program that will act as a sign of quality to the consumers and consequently increase sales for domestic agricultural goods as well as grant local producers an advantage to compete on a larger scale and possibly export their products. This project will eventually impact the standards of living of the small local Lebanese food-production businesses, their community and the Lebanese population as a whole."

"Numerous economic experts assert that for developing nations like Lebanon to regain financial stability, it is vital to concentrate investment efforts on internal resources such as the Food & Beverage and tourism sectors. A significant portion of the Lebanese population has already begun establishing small-scale agro-food and Mounet production enterprises, with many now poised to expand their operations to a larger scale and reach broader markets.

This project aims to support small, local Lebanese food-production businesses, enabling them to become self-sufficient and, in turn, improve the standard of living for both their local communities and the Lebanese population as a whole. Local entrepreneurs who satisfy the project's selection criteria will receive expert guidance and training from professional food safety specialists and business advisors. This support will equip them with the knowledge necessary to enhance product quality, leverage their competitive advantage, and integrate into more extensive markets, all while maintaining food safety standards and ensuring efficient delivery systems. This aligns with the global movement towards sustainable agri-food market patterns, which prioritize food security, nutrition, and environmental concerns (Borsellino et al., 2020)
"

In Lebanon, small-scale agricultural producers are struggling to stay in business due to unfavorable and unstable economic conditions. Despite the country's relatively favorable environmental and agricultural conditions, Lebanon imports the majority of its agricultural goods, primarily attributable to producers' limited production capabilities and knowledge. According to Lebanese Customs statistics, Lebanon's total agricultural imports reached $2.3 billion in 2021.

Numerous economic experts assert that for developing nations like Lebanon to regain financial stability, it is vital to concentrate investment efforts on internal resources such as the Food & Beverage and tourism sectors. A significant portion of the Lebanese population has already begun establishing small-scale agro-food and Mounet production enterprises, with many now poised to expand their operations to a larger scale and reach broader markets.

This proposed project aims to promote domestic agricultural production as an import substitution tool by building the

In Lebanon, small-scale agricultural producers are grappling with the challenges of staying in business amid unfavorable and unstable economic conditions. Despite the country's relatively favorable environmental and agricultural conditions, Lebanon imports the majority of its agricultural goods due to producers' limited production capabilities and knowledge. According to Lebanese Customs statistics, Lebanon's total agricultural imports reached $2.3 billion in 2021.

Numerous economic experts assert that for developing nations like Lebanon to regain financial stability, it is vital to concentrate investment efforts on internal resources such as the Food & Beverage and tourism sectors. A significant portion of the Lebanese population has already begun establishing small-scale agro-food and Mounet production enterprises, with many now poised to expand their operations to a larger scale and reach broader markets.

This proposed project aims to promote domestic agricultural production as an import substitution tool by building the capacity of Lebanese producers, supporting small, local Lebanese food-production businesses, and enabling them to become self-sufficient. In turn, this will improve the standard of living for both their local communities and the Lebanese population as a whole. The project will target around 700 producers from all over Lebanon, offering them expert guidance and training from professional food safety specialists and business advisors.

Through the design and implementation of a hybrid and innovative training curriculum, Lebanese producers will receive (1) technical and professional capacity building, and (2) universal and organizational/enterprise skills training. Upon completing the training, these producers will become eligible to receive (3) a nationally-recognized production label created and offered by the program. This label will serve as a sign of quality to consumers, consequently increasing sales for domestic agricultural goods and granting local producers an advantage to compete on a larger scale and potentially export their products.

By prioritizing food security, nutrition, and environmental concerns, this project aligns with the global movement towards sustainable agri-food market patterns (Borsellino et al., 2020), ultimately benefiting small local Lebanese food-production businesses, their communities, and the Lebanese population as a whole.

can you continue this and increase the conclusion and make it more inspiring: Project Summary 

In Lebanon, small-scale agricultural producers are grappling with the challenges of staying in business amid unfavorable and unstable economic conditions. Despite the country's relatively favorable environmental and agricultural conditions, Lebanon imports the majority of its agricultural goods due to producers' limited production capabilities and knowledge. According to Lebanese Customs statistics, Lebanon's total agricultural imports reached $2.3 billion in 2021.

Economic experts assert that for developing nations like Lebanon to regain financial stability, it is vital to concentrate investment efforts on internal resources such as the Food & Beverage and tourism sectors. A significant portion of the Lebanese population has already begun establishing small-scale agro-food and Mounet production enterprises, with many now poised to expand their operations to a larger scale and reach broader markets.

This proposed project aims to promote domestic agricultural production as an import substitution tool by building the capacity of Lebanese producers, supporting small, local Lebanese food-production businesses, and enabling them to become self-sufficient. In turn, this will improve the standard of living for both their local communities and the Lebanese population as a whole. The project will target around 700 producers from all over Lebanon, offering them expert guidance and training from professional food safety specialists and business advisors.

Through the design and implementation of a hybrid and innovative training curriculum, Lebanese producers will receive (1) technical and professional capacity building, and (2) universal and organizational/enterprise skills training. Upon completing the training, these producers will become eligible to receive (3) a nationally-recognized production label created and offered by the program. This label will serve as a sign of quality to consumers, consequently increasing sales for domestic agricultural goods and granting local producers an advantage to compete on a larger scale and potentially export their products.

Moreover, this project begins the process of creating certifications of trust, enabling businesses to demonstrate their commitment to quality and safety. To assess the efficacy of the new food production methods, entrepreneurs will submit their products for pre- and post-assessment, with successful participants becoming eligible to receive a certification label for their products. This certification will grant them a competitive edge in larger markets and, potentially, the ability to export their products.

By acquiring this label, small food-production businesses will improve brand recognition and assure customers of their products' quality. Furthermore, they will provide evidence to both internal and external authorities that their production facilities are safe and compliant with regulations. In addition, these small producers will benefit from being identified as Certified Food Production Facilities, which will:

Enhance their brand’s credibility.
Secure Customer confidence.
Protect the whole supply chain.
Acquire a competitive edge. 
Drive growth and gain market access across the world. 
Improve supplier standards and consistency in raw material
Provide concise information to assist with due diligence 


By prioritizing food security, nutrition, and environmental concerns in the path towards certification, this project aligns with the global movement towards sustainable agri-food market patterns (Borsellino et al., 2020), ultimately benefiting small local Lebanese food-production businesses, their communities, and the Lebanese population as a whole.

The selection of producers will be determined through the utilization of questionnaires, surveys, and field visits, which will enable a comprehensive assessment of their suitability for this project. The gathered data will be analyzed to ascertain the specific type and extent of assistance required for each participant. Based on these findings, we will develop a comprehensive curriculum that encompasses the following topics:

Good Manufacturing & Hygienic Practices Training
Marketing, Digital Marketing, and Branding/Communication and Leadership
Introduction to Accounting and Cost Analysis: Training on efficient methods of accounting, proper cost analysis, and bookkeeping
Personal Development and Soft Skills

Project Summary

In Lebanon, small-scale agricultural producers face significant challenges in sustaining their businesses

Despite the country's relatively favorable environmental and agricultural conditions, Lebanon imports the majority of its agricultural goods due to producers' limited production capabilities and knowledge. According to Lebanese Customs statistics, Lebanon's total agricultural imports reached $2.3 billion in 2021.

Economic experts assert that for developing nations like Lebanon to regain financial stability, it is vital to concentrate investment efforts on internal resources such as the Food & Beverage and tourism sectors. A significant portion of the Lebanese population has already begun establishing small-scale agro-food and Mounet production enterprises, with many now poised to expand their operations to a larger scale and reach broader markets.

This proposed project aims to promote domestic agricultural production as an import substitution tool by building the capacity of Lebanese producers, supporting small, local Lebanese food-production businesses, and enabling them to become self-sufficient. In turn, this will improve the standard of living for both their local communities and the Lebanese population as a whole. The project will target around 700 producers from all over Lebanon, offering them expert guidance and training from professional food safety specialists and business advisors.

This certification will grant them a competitive edge in larger markets and, potentially, the ability to export their products.

By acquiring this label, small food-production businesses will improve brand recognition and assure customers of their products' quality. Furthermore, they will provide evidence to both internal and external authorities that their production facilities are safe and compliant with regulations. In addition, these small producers will benefit from being identified as Certified Food Production Facilities, which will:

Secure Customer confidence.
Protect the whole supply chain.
Acquire a competitive edge. 
Drive growth and gain market access across the world. 
Improve supplier standards and consistency in raw material
Provide concise information to assist with due diligence 


By prioritizing food security, nutrition, and environmental concerns in the path towards certification, this project aligns with the global movement towards sustainable agri-food market patterns (Borsellino et al., 2020), ultimately benefiting small local Lebanese food-production businesses, their communities, and the Lebanese population as a whole.

The gathered data will be analyzed to ascertain the specific type and extent of assistance required for each participant. Good Manufacturing & Hygienic Practices Training
Marketing, Digital Marketing, and Branding/Communication and Leadership

Personal Development and Soft Skills

Conclusion:

can you continue read this and then write only the conclusion, make it longer and more inspiring: Project Summary

Project Summary

In Lebanon, small-scale agricultural producers are grappling with the challenges of staying in business amid unfavorable and unstable economic conditions. Despite the country's relatively favorable environmental and agricultural conditions, Lebanon imports the majority of its agricultural goods due to producers' limited production capabilities and knowledge. According to Lebanese Customs statistics, Lebanon's total agricultural imports reached $2.3 billion in 2021.

Economic experts assert that for developing nations like Lebanon to regain financial stability, it is vital to concentrate investment efforts on internal resources such as the Food & Beverage and tourism sectors. A significant portion of the Lebanese population has already begun establishing small-scale agro-food and Mounet production enterprises, with many now poised to expand their operations to a larger scale and reach broader markets.

This proposed project aims to promote domestic agricultural production as an import substitution tool by building the capacity of Lebanese producers, supporting small, local Lebanese food-production businesses, and enabling them to become self-sufficient. In turn, this will improve the standard of living for both their local communities and the Lebanese population as a whole. The project will target around 700 producers from all over Lebanon, offering them expert guidance and training from professional food safety specialists and business advisors.

Through the design and implementation of a hybrid and innovative training curriculum, Lebanese producers will receive (1) technical and professional capacity building, and (2) universal and organizational/enterprise skills training. Upon completing the training, these producers will become eligible to receive (3) a nationally-recognized production label created and offered by the program. This label will serve as a sign of quality to consumers, consequently increasing sales for domestic agricultural goods and granting local producers an advantage to compete on a larger scale and potentially export their products.

Moreover, this project begins the process of creating certifications of trust, enabling businesses to demonstrate their commitment to quality and safety. To assess the efficacy of the new food production methods, entrepreneurs will submit their products for pre- and post-assessment, with successful participants becoming eligible to receive a certification label for their products. This certification will grant them a competitive edge in larger markets and, potentially, the ability to export their products.

By acquiring this label, small food-production businesses will improve brand recognition and assure customers of their products' quality. Furthermore, they will provide evidence to both internal and external authorities that their production facilities are safe and compliant with regulations. In addition, these small producers will benefit from being identified as Certified Food Production Facilities, which will:

Enhance their brand’s credibility.
Secure Customer confidence.
Protect the whole supply chain.
Acquire a competitive edge. 
Drive growth and gain market access across the world. 
Improve supplier standards and consistency in raw material
Provide concise information to assist with due diligence 

By prioritizing food security, nutrition, and environmental concerns in the path towards certification, this project aligns with the global movement towards sustainable agri-food market patterns (Borsellino et al., 2020), ultimately benefiting small local Lebanese food-production businesses, their communities, and the Lebanese population as a whole.

The selection of producers will be determined through the utilization of questionnaires, surveys, and field visits, which will enable a comprehensive assessment of their suitability for this project. The gathered data will be analyzed to ascertain the specific type and extent of assistance required for each participant. Based on these findings, we will develop a comprehensive curriculum that encompasses the following topics:

Good Manufacturing & Hygienic Practices Training
Marketing, Digital Marketing, and Branding/Communication and Leadership
Introduction to Accounting and Cost Analysis: Training on efficient methods of accounting, proper cost analysis, and bookkeeping
Personal Development and Soft Skills

Conclusion:

This project presents a transformative opportunity to empower small-scale Lebanese agricultural producers and redefine the nation's agri-food landscape. By embracing a hands-on, immersive approach to

learning, we will help these entrepreneurs unleash their potential, achieve self-sufficiency, and contribute to the country's economic growth. During the training, participants will be asked to develop a business plan outlining their future strategy and presenting a five-year growth projection. This exercise will not only solidify their newfound skills but also foster a forward-thinking mindset and encourage long-term planning.

The ripple effect of this project extends beyond the individual producers, as it holds the promise of revitalizing local communities, promoting job creation, and enhancing the overall standard of living for the Lebanese population. By fostering a culture of innovation, sustainability, and collaboration, we aim to create a more resilient and self-reliant agri-food sector that can withstand economic challenges and uncertainties.

This project aspires to serve as a beacon of hope and inspiration for Lebanon, demonstrating that through targeted investment, education, and the empowerment of local entrepreneurs, the nation can harness its abundant natural resources, rich cultural heritage, and entrepreneurial spirit to build a brighter, more prosperous future.

As we embark on this journey, let us remember that the power of change lies within each participant, their unwavering determination, and their passion for growth. Together, we can elevate Lebanon's agri-food industry, create a lasting impact on the nation's economy, and ensure that future generations inherit a thriving, sustainable legacy.
